item.title: Bicycling
item.description: This is a chronological account of my experiences with cycling, with a distribution of about 50% memoir and 50% op-ed. During middle school I got my first bike, a “hybrid” Trek FX 2. My dad and I spent a couple of summers riding a section of the Heritage Trail, a rail-trail in Orange County, semi-regularly. I have very fond memories of those rides and they kickstarted what will presumably be a lifelong love of cycling.

item.title: Keyboards
item.description: I type on a split, ergonomic, 34-key keyboard. This is the result of a rabbit hole I went down in 2021 or so. In retrospect it was quite a valuable hobby to pick up; I learned how to solder microelectronics, the basics of PCB design, and to this day I type faster and more efficiently than I ever did before. Sweep The first keyboard I built, without any experience soldering or working with a bill of materials, was the Sweep, a popular open-source keyboard design.

item.description: Here are five songs that encapsulate my taste well. All links are to Bandcamp. item.title: Name
item.description: The name Aron doesn’t really mean anything. It’s little more than an unusual spelling of Aaron. According to my parents it’s supposed to be pronounced /ærɪn/ (like the a in “ash”) but I guess Aaron is pronounced like /ɛrɪn/ (like “air-in”) so I’m mostly called that. Language is fluid so I let it slide. Whenever people ask I tell them to pronounce it the way they normally would.
